item.title: Ljubljana, Slovenia and Zagreb, Croatia
item.dc:creator: monicaspitzer
item.description: On our road trip down to Dubrovnik, we stopped for 2 hours in Ljubljana and then spent the night in Zagreb. Ljubljana had a lovely old town area that definitely required more time to explore than the 2 hours we were given. I only was able to see the old city of Zagreb at night, [...]
item.content:encoded:
On our road trip down to Dubrovnik, we stopped for 2 hours in Ljubljana and then spent the night in Zagreb. Ljubljana had a lovely old town area that definitely required more time to explore than the 2 hours we were given. I only was able to see the old city of Zagreb at night, but it had a very vibrant atmosphere and I would love to go back and visit for a longer time. Before we left for Dubrovnik in the morning, we attended a lecture at the law faculty at the University of Zagreb.

Ljubljana

A sundial on the wall of a church in the old city of Ljubljana

There were weird scultures all along the sides of this bridge. Are these supposed to be dragon skulls?

This painting, located in the law building at the University of Zagreb, depicts the development of the school.

This is the Croatian National Theatre of Zagreb, across the street from the law school building where we attended a lecture.

item.title: Books for Brainiacs (literally)
item.dc:creator: Morgan Mussell
item.description: I was browsing the NPR list of recommended Sci-Fi titles today, and could barely manage a ho-hum.  I’ve slipped into one of my periodic non-fiction moods, and I’ve learned to follow such whims to see where they take me.  I fear that my book queue may get even more unmanageable after stumbling upon these NPR [...]
item.content:encoded:
I was browsing the NPR list of recommended Sci-Fi titles today, and could barely manage a ho-hum.  I’ve slipped into one of my periodic non-fiction moods, and I’ve learned to follow such whims to see where they take me.  I fear that my book queue may get even more unmanageable after stumbling upon these NPR recommendations:  Insane Science:  Five New Books that Explain the Brain.  http://www.npr.org/2011/06/08/136896426/insane-science-5-new-books-that-explain-the-brain  Here is a quick summary of the article:

The Compass Of Pleasure: How Our Brains Make Fatty Foods, Orgasm, Exercise, Marijuana, Generosity, Vodka, Learning, And Gambling Feel So Good  by David J. Linden.  Everyone probably guessed Fatty Foods, Orgasm, Vodka, and perhaps Generosity, but the author claims that Paying your taxes belongs in that category too.

The Believing Brain: From Ghosts To Gods To Politics And Conspiracies — How We Construct Beliefs And Reinforce Them As Truths by Michael Shermer.  Shermer, a former Evangelical Christian who became an agnostic in college claims that belief precedes the explanations we invent for them.  However, Shermer acknowledges that, “we could be wrong.”

The Psychopath Test: A Journey Through The Madness Industry by Jon Ronson.  The bad news:  an estimated 1% of the population is psychopathic.  The good news:  if you wonder if you are, you almost certainly are not.

The Optimism Bias: A Tour Of The Irrationally Positive Brain by Tali Sharot.  Even if you are a cynic, your brain is probably hardwired for optimism.  ”Most people are programmed to predict happy endings in all facets of our lives.”  As you might have guessed, there is measurable survival value in thes.

A Billion Wicked Thoughts: What The World‘s Largest Experiment Reveals About Human Desire by Ogi Ogas and Sai Gaddam.  If you want to know what people really think about sex, look online, claim the authors, and that is what they did.  Their conclusion, after sifting through “reams” of data?  Men’s sexual brains “are more like Elmer Fudd,” and women’s, “like Miss Marple.”  That hook I think, is enough to get me to download this one.  Not that I would be crass enough to ever make a joke about Elmer Fudd and Congressman Wiener – nope, no way.

Happy reading, everyone, and I categorically deny all rumors that I have too much time on my hands!

item.title: 44. Forgetting someone’s name
item.dc:creator: edwincov
item.description: (. . . when they remember yours.) I’ve always been good at remembering names. I don’t really have to try to do it, the name just sticks to me after they mention it the first time. Unfortunately, this always makes the other person feel awkward and I finally understand why! The Barista at Starbucks remembered [...]
item.content:encoded:
(. . . when they remember yours.)

I’ve always been good at remembering names. I don’t really have to try to do it, the name just sticks to me after they mention it the first time. Unfortunately, this always makes the other person feel awkward and I finally understand why!

The Barista at Starbucks remembered me from a social gathering somewhere. I didn’t remember her, her name, or even the place where I met her, yet she knew my name. Instead of pretending that I already who she was and saying “Oh! Hey. . how’ve you been?” I was like “Oh, sorry I don’t remember you.” That’s when I realized that people avoid saying that at all cost, and that’s why they feel so awkward. Well, yeah . . . it is awkward.

How many of you have actually pretended to remember someone?

“Hey, man. How are you?”

“What’s up dude! Long time.”

You avoid any type of conversation that would include his or her name, and just wait for the name to just end up being mentioned by someone else. Or wait to see if you can somehow spot the name on the person’s notebook. Or see if you steal their wallet and then check their I.D. (not advised). Oh, here’s a good one:

Me: Hey, so yeah man.. how do you spell your name again?

“Man”: Uh, Andrew?

Me: Yeah, but you know . . how do you spell it? (awkward) Since there are so many different (awkward) spellings for a single name nowadays.

Andrew: Oh, right! A-N-D-R-E-W ha, ha!

Me: Cool, so it’s uh, normal. Cool.

PHEEW! Saved!  ..sort of.

Image source

item.title: Tony’s Darts Away Beer Class 101
item.dc:creator: the minty
item.description: Personally I like to yell and sulk around beer when I agitate it. Oh wait. Last week, I was invited to Tony’s Darts Away for a special Beer Class with Paige from Tony’s Darts Away and Ting from Eagle Rock Brewery. We tasted 9 different craft beers and I learned quite a bit about the [...]
item.content:encoded:
Personally I like to yell and sulk around beer when I agitate it. Oh wait.

Last week, I was invited to Tony’s Darts Away for a special Beer Class with Paige from Tony’s Darts Away and Ting from Eagle Rock Brewery. We tasted 9 different craft beers and I learned quite a bit about the art of brewing beer.

barley for making pilsner

Now, we all know the Minty is a cocktailian. This means I drink cocktails. I drink wine on occasion and beer even less frequently. But every now and then I like to mix it up and I particularly love learning. The only time I’ve had a brewery tour was at Sam Adams in Boston. There, I learned beer was made with water, barley, hops and yeast. They they gave you a couple of beers to taste and out the door you go within an hour. With Paige and Ting, they went beyond “water, barley, hops and yeast” to provide a deeper understanding of why beer taste good.

c-120 malted barley

black malted barley

Then we delved deeper in the world of barley and malts. I had no idea it wasn’t just the barley I buy to make soup. They brought a few different ones for us to compare. From what goes into pilsners to c-120 (C stands for caramel) to even “black.” Later we would learn there are some who decry the practice of adding anything but the water, barley, hops and yeast to make beer. The flavors you taste mostly come from what kind of barley you’re adding. Hops is what gives beer its degree of bitterness as well as some flavor and aroma.

simcoe whole hops

cascade hops

We looked at whole  hops and also pellets (there was some joking about hops and cannabis being related plants).

Ting of Eagle Rock Brewery with Paige of Tony's Darts Away

We then learned after the basic four ingredients, there are “adjuncts.” These additions can be anything from rolled oats for an oatmeal stout or brown sugar for a scotch ale.

Craftsman 1903 Lager

Black Market Brown Ale

Russian River Blind Pig IPA

We started our beer tasting with Pasadena’s Craftsman 1903 lager. I am personally more of a fan of darker beers but this was a great beer to sip with the sausage I was eating at the time. I did like the Black Market brown ale more. And Santa Rosa’s Russian River Blind Pig IPA was very floral. I think it’s great Tony’s Darts Away serves only California craft beer.

pork sausage

Mm, sausage

Besides the sausage (pork, chicken or veg), Tony’s started offering two burgers bi-weekly this past Sunday. Look for ever-changing burger options including a vegetarian burger. Tony’s does an interesting vegan poutine.

vegan poutine

These fries were tasty! But it was obvious that our meat-lovin’ group  preferred the non-vegan one. We demolished the meaty poutine.

Cismontane/ Tustin Brewing El Toro Trio Hafer Weizen

Iron Fist Dubbel Fisted Belgian-style Dubbel

Eagle Rock Solidarity Mild

The Hafen Weizen is actually a collaboration between Cismontane and Tustin Brewing. The beer, El Toro Trio Hafer Weizen, tasted full-bodied yet crisp to me. Some asked about adding an orange or lemon wedge but it seemed frowned upon. Besides liking porters and stouts, I am fond of Belgian beer and Iron Fist Dubbel Fisted Belgian-style Dubbel was a fun beer as well as a fun name.  When I visited the Eagle Rock Brewery for my Craft Beer Crawl, I was a bit overwhelmed by the crowd and didn’t spend any time discussing what I liked with the counter guy. I probably should have so I would have ended up with something I liked better. Or I now know I like the Eagle Rock Solidarity Mild. It smells a bit like coffee and has a hint of that flavor to me.

The Bruery Trade Winds

Hangar 24 Orange Wheat

AVBC Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

The final trio was The Bruery Trade Winds Tripel which I liked for its slight fizz. I didn’t expect to like Hangar 24 Orange Wheat at all but I can imagine this light beer on the patio with a plate of cheese and crackers. It’s the perfect late afternoon brew. But of all the things I tasted this night, my fave was AVBC Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout. I did say I liked porter and stouts! Also, I had a slight sore throat at the time and the somewhat slippery (gotta love oatmeal!) beer slid down easily versus the  more acidic beers (which is not to say they wouldn’t be great if I hadn’t been sick– but I do recommend NOT ordering oh, Hafer Weizen when you’re sick).

Eagle Rock Brewery

3056 Roswell Street
Los Angeles, CA 90065

Tony’s Darts Away

1710 West Magnolia Boulevard
Burbank, CA 91506
(818) 253-1710

item.title: D.I.Y. matchbook notepads
item.dc:creator: Paige
item.description: This inspired little project from Fossil has been making the rounds on several of my favorite blogs. Simple and charming, they are a perfect, pocket-sized medium for expressing your love. I absolutely loved them as a Mother’s Day gift, and set about making one myself. Because of my generally messy handwriting, I had to improvise, making [...]
item.content:encoded:
This inspired little project from Fossil has been making the rounds on several of my favorite blogs. Simple and charming, they are a perfect, pocket-sized medium for expressing your love.

I absolutely loved them as a Mother’s Day gift, and set about making one myself. Because of my generally messy handwriting, I had to improvise, making it a bit bigger than the tutorial shows. Also, instead of the fabric or paper scraps, I drew a silhouette of her schnauzer, Archie, cut it out and glued it in one corner.

It’s not nearly as impressive as Fossil’s version. The staples are a bit crooked, the pages aren’t all the same size, and my corners are anything but sharp.

Granted, I’ve progressed enough to get beyond the Sculpey clay ducks and colored bookmarks. But I still can’t cut clean corners. I’m still imperfect and messy. I still spill glue, wreck my bicycle and burn myself in the kitchen. I still don’t dust as well as she does, and still have to ask her opinion on certain recipes.

I still need my mama.

I think she likes it that way.

item.title: Rounded Spectacles
item.dc:creator: BeeofDesign
item.description: I have a love-hate relationship with glasses. They have been a must of mine since the age of 5 and not all pairs have been flattering. In fact it was not until recently that I wore them outside of the house. My latest pair of purchase are round, tortoise color, harry-potter like frames. (click to see) [...]
item.content:encoded:
I have a love-hate relationship with glasses. They have been a must of mine since the age of 5 and not all pairs have been flattering. In fact it was not until recently that I wore them outside of the house. My latest pair of purchase are round, tortoise color, harry-potter like frames. (click to see) It was a bold move. I was nervous about taking such a risk on a huge investment but now they have become a recognizable staple. People don’t recognize me without them.  Now with the influx of fresh frames – above example from Elizabeth and James spring line – I have more to lust over. In an extravagant  world I would have multiple pairs of glasses to chose from at the whim of an outfit change.

Oh… to dream.

item.title: Don’t Let This Face Fool You
item.dc:creator: Allison
item.description: In no particular order, Zoe has ingested the following objects: A cat’s toy mouse covered with red feathers 3 rather large peach pits An armada of battle ship pegs (hits and misses) If there is something gross to eat in the yard– and there always is– Zoe will find it. At 10 years of age, [...]
item.content:encoded:
In no particular order, Zoe has ingested the following objects:

  • A cat’s toy mouse covered with red feathers
  • 3 rather large peach pits
  • An armada of battle ship pegs (hits and misses)

If there is something gross to eat in the yard– and there always is– Zoe will find it.

At 10 years of age, she took up shoe destruction (see exhibit A).  At 11 years of age, she discovered the toilet paper roll.

Exhibit A

Her saving grace is how much Abby adores her.  And that, with a blanket piled just right next to me, she makes the perfect reading companion– that is, when she’s not busy looking for dangerous object to ingest.

item.title: Make ‘em go “oh, oh, oh!”
item.dc:creator: brandonkawamura
item.description: I have two confessions: one is that it’s been way too long since I went out and took some photos, and two, is I love the Katy Perry song “Firework” more than I should. Yesterday was the HawaiiPhotoForum fireworks photo meet at Magic Island.  Every Friday Night, The Hilton Hawaiian Village puts on a 4-ish minute [...]
item.content:encoded:
I have two confessions: one is that it’s been way too long since I went out and took some photos, and two, is I love the Katy Perry song “Firework” more than I should.

Yesterday was the HawaiiPhotoForum fireworks photo meet at Magic Island.  Every Friday Night, The Hilton Hawaiian Village puts on a 4-ish minute long Fireworks display so the group decided we’d practice our fireworks photography technique.  It was great seeing everyone again, and great to have an excuse to take photos.  As per usual, I didn’t take as many photos as I should have, and I wound up mostly disappointed that I didn’t get the shot I was looking for, and that I didn’t think of some cool ideas that some of the other photographers did.  It gives me something to try next time.  Fireworks bokeh is beautiful!

Magic Island is, of course, a great vantage point to photograph the iconic Diamond Head landmark, so here’s my obligatory photo.  I was going for an old-hawaii aged look on this one.

There were a lot of boats on this furlough Friday.  For this photo, I decided to try playing up the blues so the ocean would look like it does when driving around the Makapu’u side of the island.

I liked the symmetry of the paddlers in this shot.

The End.
